\&quot;people\&quot; can be mentioned in rich text objects or in people properties of databases. Trying to include users of type \&quot;bot\&quot; will return a validation error. Existing mentions of bot users is unaffected.\n\n## July 1, 2021\n\n### Page objects now contain url\n\n[Page objects](ref:page#all-pages) now return the web address of the page in the `url` key. \n\n```json\n{\n  \&quot;object\&quot;: \&quot;page\&quot;,\n  \&quot;id\&quot;: \&quot;251d2b5f-268c-4de2-afe9-c71ff92ca95c\&quot;,\n\t\&quot;created_time\&quot;: \&quot;2020-03-17T19:10:04.968Z\&quot;,\n\t\&quot;last_edited_time\&quot;: \&quot;2020-03-17T21:49:37.913Z\&quot;,\n  \&quot;parent\&quot;: {\n    \&quot;type\&quot;: \&quot;database_id\&quot;,\n    \&quot;database_id\&quot;: \&quot;48f8fee9-cd79-4180-bc2f-ec0398253067\&quot;\n  },\n  \&quot;archived\&quot;: false,\n  \&quot;url\&quot;: \&quot;https://www.notion.so/Avocado-251d2b5f268c4de2afe9c71ff92ca95c\&quot;,\n  \&quot;properties\&quot;: {\n    \&quot;Name\&quot;: {\n      \&quot;id\&quot;: \&quot;title\&quot;,\n      \&quot;type\&quot;: \&quot;title\&quot;,\n      \&quot;title\&quot;: [\n        {\n          \&quot;type\&quot;: \&quot;text\&quot;,\n          \&quot;text\&quot;: {\n            \&quot;content\&quot;: \&quot;Avocado\&quot;,\n            \&quot;link\&quot;: null\n          },\n          \&quot;annotations\&quot;: {\n            \&quot;bold\&quot;: false,\n            \&quot;italic\&quot;: false,\n            \&quot;strikethrough\&quot;: false,\n            \&quot;underline\&quot;: false,\n            \&quot;code\&quot;: false,\n            \&quot;color\&quot;: \&quot;default\&quot;\n          },\n          \&quot;plain_text\&quot;: \&quot;Avocado\&quot;,\n          \&quot;href\&quot;: null\n        }\n      ]\n    }\n  }\n}\n```\n\nThis impacts endpoints that return page object: the [pages](ref:page) endpoints and [query database](ref:post-database-query) endpoint.\n\n## June 28, 2021\n\n### Last edited and created time properties are now rounded to the nearest minute\n\nStarting July 1st, the `last_edited_time` and `created_time` properties will be rounded down to the closest minute for `page`, `database` , and `block` objects. Previously, this behavior was inconsistent with some times being rounded and others not.\n\n## June 23, 2021\n\n### Database objects now return parent\n\nDatabase objects now return a [parent property](ref:database#page-parent). Databases can have pages or workspaces as parents.\n\n```json\n{\n  \&quot;parent\&quot;: {\n    \&quot;type\&quot;: \&quot;page_id\&quot;,\n    \&quot;page_id\&quot;: \&quot;b8595b75-abd1-4cad-8dfe-f935a8ef57cb\&quot;\n}\n```\n\n### Other Improvements and Fixes\n\n- Inline database mentions are now included in [rich_text mention](ref:rich-text#database-mentions) responses.\n- When an integration does not have access to a [page or database mention](ref:rich-text#page-mentions), we will no longer completely omit the mention. The mention will be returned with just the ID but without detailed information (title will appear as \&quot;Untitled\&quot; and annotations will be default).\n- When integrations are added to pages inside collections they can now always update page properties, even when the integration does not have access to the parent database. However, integrations will not be able to add new [select](ref:page#select-property-values) or [multi-select](ref:page#multi-select-property-values) properties through the create or update page endpoints without the ability to edit the database parent.\n\n## June 15, 2021\n\n### Select values can now be dynamically created via Create and Update Page endpoints + other updates since public beta launch\n\nYou can now dynamically create new options for [Select](ref:database#select-configuration) or  [Multi-Select properties](ref:database#multi-select-configuration) when using the [Create Page](ref:post-page) and [Update Page](ref:patch-page) endpoints. When specifying an option that does not exist in the database schema already, the option will now be created and the database schema updated accordingly. \n\n```json\n{\n  \&quot;properties\&quot;: {\n    \&quot;Food group\&quot;: {\n      \&quot;multi_select\&quot;: [{\&quot;name\&quot;: \&quot;Vegetable\&quot;},{\&quot;name\&quot;: \&quot;Fruit\&quot;}]\n    }\n  }\n}\n```\n\nIn the above [property values](ref:page-property-value) example: Previously, if either \&quot;Vegetable\&quot; or \&quot;Fruit\&quot; did not already exist as an option in the database schema, an error would be returned that these are not valid Select options. Now, these options will be created dynamically.\n\n**Bug Fixes**\n\n- The title property of a page can be set, and a page can be archived or un-archived, even when the page does not belong to a database.\n- [Retrieving pages](ref:get-page) that are shared with an integration, but where the page's parent is not shared, no longer erroneously returns a 404.\n\n**Other Changes**\n\n- [Search endpoint](ref:post-search) now returns untitled pages.\n- Applies to [version 2021-05-13](versioning#changes-by-version) and later only: The [Query Database](ref:post-database-query) endpoint no longer accepts query parameters ‚Äì these should be sent as body parameters.\n\n## May 19, 2021\n\n### \&quot;Notion-Version\&quot; header will be required starting June 1, 2021\n\nThe Notion API has recommended using an explicit version to every HTTP request, using the `Notion-Version` header. **For integrations created after June 1, 2021 an explicit version on every request will become required**. After July 1, 2021, integrations created before June 1, 2021 will also have the same requirement. Today, the most recent version is `\&quot;2021-05-13\&quot;`.\n\n#### Is my integration affected? What should I do to update?\n\nThis requirement will not break your existing integration; however, we will start enforcing this requirement for all API requests on July 1st. Starting July 1st, if you don't send the Notion-Version header with your Notion API calls, you will get a [`\&quot;missing_version\&quot;` error](ref:errors). Learn more about how the Notion API [handles versioning](ref:versioning).\n\nIf you've been using examples copied from documentation or example code since the public beta, including using the [Notion SDK for JavaScript](https://github.com/makenotion/notion-sdk-js), your existing code should continue to work as expected.\n\nOtherwise, please make one of the two following changes before July 1:\n\n1. Add `Notion-Version: 2021-05-11` in the header when making requests (no other code change is needed).\n2. **Recommended**: Add `Notion-Version: 2021-05-13` in the header when making requests.  Making this change will move you to our newest version which includes the following breaking change.\n\n#### Breaking changes in version `2021-05-13`\n\nThe `type` of [property value objects](ref:page-property-value) for rich text properties has changed from `\&quot;text\&quot;` to `\&quot;rich_text\&quot;`.\n\nWhen [creating pages](ref:post-page) and [updating page properties](ref:patch-page), update page property values that are rich text to use the key `rich_text` instead of `text`. Similarly when [retrieving a page](ref:get-page), rich text properties will be returned with the `type`  `\&quot;rich_text\&quot;` instead of `\&quot;text\&quot;`.\n\nThis change helps distinguish between the property type, and the inner text values of [rich text object](ref:rich-text), which have the key `text`.\n\nTo illustrate this change, here is an example of how the [page object](ref:page)'s `properties` appear before and after:\n\n```js\n// Before (in unversioned requests and responses)\n{\n  \&quot;object\&quot;: \&quot;page\&quot;,\n  \&quot;properties\&quot;: {\n    \&quot;Description\&quot;: {\n      \&quot;type\&quot;: \&quot;text\&quot;,\n      \&quot;text\&quot;: [\n        {\n          \&quot;type\&quot;: \&quot;text\&quot;,\n          \&quot;text\&quot;: { \&quot;content\&quot;: \&quot;Hello World\&quot; }\n        }\n      ]\n    }\n  }\n  /* remaining details omitted */\n}\n```\n\n```js\n// After (in requests and responses with version 2021-05-13)\n{\n  \&quot;object\&quot;: \&quot;page\&quot;,\n  \&quot;properties\&quot;: {\n    \&quot;Description\&quot;: {\n      \&quot;type\&quot;: \&quot;rich_text\&quot;,\n      \&quot;rich_text\&quot;: [\n        {\n          \&quot;type\&quot;: \&quot;text\&quot;,\n          \&quot;text\&quot;: { \&quot;content\&quot;: \&quot;Hello World\&quot; }\n        }\n      ]\n    }\n  }\n  /* remaining details omitted */\n}\n```\n\n## May 18, 2021\n\n### Initial users may reauthorize a public integration using OAuth\n\nPublic integrations use OAuth to [request authorization from a user](https://developers.notion.com/docs/authorization#prompting-users-to-add-an-integration) before being added to a Notion workspace. Previously, once an integration was added to a workspace, no users were able to reauthorize the same integration in that workspace. This change allows the user who initially added the integration to complete the authorization flow more than once. This improvement helps integrations avoid a potential dead end in user flows.\n\nIntegrations do not need to make any updates to take advantage of this new capability. An integration may simply link or redirect a user to the authorization URL, the same as the first authorization. During reauthorization the user will not see the page picker. The access token received at the end of reauthorization will be the same as the initial access token. This capability is available immediately.\n\nPlease be aware that other previous limitations still exist. Only users with admin access level in a workspace can add an integration. Integrations can only be added to a workspace by one user.\n\n## May 13, 2021\n\n### Hello world, the Notion API is now in public beta\n\nThe Notion API is now available for all developers to explore and build upon. Integrations built on the API are available to all Notion users, on free or paid plans.\n\nIn this public beta release, you'll find many of the fundamental parts of Notion: reading and writing to pages, working with users, and the deep and powerful world of Notion databases. The API itself offers foundational features such as authorization, pagination, limits, and more. This is enough to build many interesting integrations we've heard Notion users are excited to use. We're excited to see what you'll build for all of us. &lt;a href=\&quot;https://developers.notion.com/docs/getting-started\&quot;&gt;‚Üí Get started&lt;/a&gt;\n\nOur goal is to establish that the Notion API is robust, easy to use, and trustworthy. In public beta, we‚Äôll continue to add new features and making significant changes based on your feedback. Once the most important improvements are included, the API will transition from public beta to general availability. you‚Äôll have everything you need to build integrations teams and businesses can depend on.\n\nA special thanks to the all developers who experimented, explored, and shared their ideas with us - both in the private beta and those following along.\n\n## May 4, 2021\n\n### Public integration type extends access to multiple workspaces using OAuth\n\nThe Notion API has added a new integration type: Public OAuth integrations. If you're building a product or service for Notion users outside your own team - public integrations are for developers like you. \n\nIn order to create and configure an integration, its type, name, avatar, and other related settings, the &lt;a href=\&quot;https://www.notion.com/my-integrations\&quot;&gt;My integrations&lt;/a&gt; page is now available.\n\nPublic integrations use OAuth to request permission to access pages and databases in new workspaces. Once the user accepts, the integration can receive a separate access token for resources in the user's workspace.\n\nExisting integrations are now known as internal integrations. We no longer call the bearer token you previously used an API Key. It's now known as an integration token. You can keep your bearer token around - it will continue to work just the same.\n\nLearn how to implement these changes in the &lt;a href=\&quot;https://developers.notion.com/docs/authorization\&quot;&gt;authorization guide&lt;/a&gt;.\n\n## May 3, 2021\n\n### Search is now available in the API\n\nUsing the new &lt;a href=\&quot;https://developers.notion.com/reference/post-search\&quot;&gt;search endpoint&lt;/a&gt;, you can query all pages and databases users have shared with your integration.\n\nThe query you provide filters results by matching against the page title. The results also include matches against subpages of pages users have shared with your integration. This endpoint can be helpful when onboarding a new user and trying to find the page they just shared with your integration.\n\nWe recommend transitioning away from using the &lt;a href=\&quot;https://developers.notion.com/reference/get-databases\&quot;&gt;list databases endpoint&lt;/a&gt;. The search endpoint provides all the same functionality - and
